text: Let's go over the basics
of recording your first podcast.
In this video,

we will cover recording
your microphone of choice
into a USB interface or external recorder.
Use our clickable sections

to navigate to the recording
device you are using.
A USB audio interface is a great option
for recording a podcast.
It also requires a computer and software
to record the audio.

In this tutorial, we will
be using Adobe Audition
as our recording software.
If you do not have Audition,

Audacity is a free
software that's available
and has a similar setup.
See our link in the description
to learn more about how to use Audacity.

First, let's plug in our USB
interface into a computer,

then plug in the microphones
you will be using.

For this video, we'll be
using two microphones.

Depending on if your
microphone needs phantom power,
you can turn on the 48-volt power button.

Now you can check if your
microphones are working

right on the interface
by talking into them.
"Check mic one, check mic two."
Now open Audition.
Go to "File," "New,"
then select "Multitrack Session."
Label it and save.
A little tip here:
Use the highest bit depth with float
for best quality and editing performance.

Check out our other video,
"How To Edit A Podcast,"
for more on effects and audio editing.

Now let's link the
microphones we plugged in
to their own tracks to be recorded.
Go to "Track 1."
Click on the input list.
Go to "Mono"

and select "Input 1" from
your audio interface.
Do the same for Track 2,
but this time select "Input 2."

Now you need to enable
both tracks to record.
Click the "R" button on both tracks.
You can now see the audio from your mics

coming through on the individual
track level indicators.

Now test your mics to make
sure they're turned up
and not too loud.
Use the line gain on the USB interface
to make sure your loudest talking

does not cross into the red
on the track level indicator.
During the recording process,
it's a good idea to use headphones
to monitor what's being recorded.
By clicking the "I" button on each track,
you can sample your mics.
This helps with making sure
all audio is being recorded correctly

and you're actively monitoring
for noise or audio problems.

If possible, use headphones
that cover your ears completely
versus using earbuds
for a more accurate monitoring experience.

Now you can hit the "Record"
button at the bottom
and begin your podcast.
Then hit "Stop" when you're done.

From this point, you can apply
effects to your audio track,
export, and publish your podcast.

Now, if your podcast is
being recorded remotely
and away from your computer
or you don't have a USB audio interface,
you can use an external recorder.
This is a popular and easy option.

Plug in your microphones
into the recorder.
On the recorder, you can check

your microphone levels
right on the screen.
If your mics are not showing
any sound coming through them,
they may need phantom power to run.
Your recorder should have an option

to supply 48 volts of phantom
power to either input.
If your audio levels are peaking

or going above the
negative-6-decibel mark,
they may begin to distort.

Adjust the line gain
until the levels max out
at or lower than negative 6 decibels.
Now plug in some headphones

to actively monitor the quality
of your microphone audio.

Now hit "Record" and
"Stop" when you're done.

You can then take the
files from the SD card

and pull them into your
audio-editing software of choice.
